update.description:
Add mex (MATLAB / Octave) wrappers for the C functions in the new sim API.  Notes:

* ~~At the time of writing, for clarity this PR is targeted at the `sim_api` branch, upon which it relies.  Once `sim_api` is merged, this PR should be retargeted at `default`.~~
* ~~A major missing piece of this PR is documentation in each `.m` file that explains parameters and return values for each function.~~
* ~~Also missing is an example of how to use the functions.~~
 * A decent example of usage is coming together in `hxs_example.m`.
* Also missing is a test of this code (it will go into handsim).

With those caveats, I believe that this code is ready for review.

Following @jacquelinekay 's example, here's a breakdown of review responsibility (for each, please check the implementation in `hxgz.c` and the function definition and documentation in the corresponding `hxs_*.m` file):

* @caguero: `hxs_add_model, hxs_remove_model, hxs_is_logging, hxs_start_logging, hxs_stop_logging, hxs_set_model_color, hxs_model_color`
* @scpeters: `hxs_model_collide_mode, hxs_set_model_collide_mode, hxs_contacts, hxs_set_model_joint_state, hxs_set_model_link_state`
* @hsu: `hxs_model_transform, hxs_set_model_transform, hxs_angular_velocity, hxs_set_angular_velocity, hxs_linear_velocity, hxs_set_linear_velocity, hxs_sim_info`
* @jacquelinekay: `hxs_reset, hxs_apply_force, hxs_apply_wrench, hxs_apply_torque,  hxs_camera_transform, hxs_set_camera_transform, hxs_model_gravity_mode, hxs_set_model_gravity_mode`

---

To test this code in Octave on Linux:

* `sudo apt-get install liboctave-dev` (to get the `mkoctfile` compiler)
* configure, make, and install
* `gazebo worlds/arat.world`
* `cd <prefix>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave`
* `octave`

Now, at the Octave prompt, you can try any of the `hxs_*.m` functions, without the `.m` suffix.  E.g., try `hxs_sim_info`.  To run the example: `hxs_example`.
update.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

pullrequest.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

content.raw:
`<from_your_haptix-comm-repo>sh tools/code_check.sh` (you need cppcheck installed).

But this is not going to work because we are not parsing the `matlab` directory. If you look into `code_check.sh` there's a variable for specifying the directories that the checker needs to check (`CHECK_DIRS`). I played a little bit with that variable and with the `CPPCHECK_FILES` variable but for some reason didn't work. So, my workaround to see the output was to copy `hxgz.c` into the `src/` directory and renamed to `.cc`. 

And about the spacing, we don't usually have the space before the opening parenthesis but probably not a big deal.
content.html:
<from_your_haptix-comm-repo>sh tools/code_check.sh (you need cppcheck installed).

But this is not going to work because we are not parsing the matlab directory. If you look into code_check.sh there's a variable for specifying the directories that the checker needs to check (CHECK_DIRS). I played a little bit with that variable and with the CPPCHECK_FILES variable but for some reason didn't work. So, my workaround to see the output was to copy hxgz.c into the src/ directory and renamed to .cc.

And about the spacing, we don't usually have the space before the opening parenthesis but probably not a big deal.

pull_request.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

pullrequest.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

content.raw:
Thanks.  How do I run the checker?

Also, I thought that our style was to have a space before the opening `(` in a function prototype or definition.
content.html:
Thanks. How do I run the checker?

Also, I thought that our style was to have a space before the opening ( in a function prototype or definition.

content.raw: As we discussed, these functions are only used internally, and the pointer that's being passed is the address of a stack variable, which should be safe, and never NULL.
content.html: As we discussed, these functions are only used internally, and the pointer that's being passed is the address of a stack variable, which should be safe, and never NULL.
